talk.start.para: .- In answer to a question which I asked to-day, the Treasurer (Mr. Casey) said that it was the intention of the Government to invite an expert from Great Britain to advise the Ministry further in respect of national insurance. I desire to place on record my utter dissatisfaction with the manner in which the Government is attempting to evade the responsibility it has incurred as a result of the promises made in the Prime Minister's policy speech at the. last election. Although a considerable period has elapsed since then, nothing has been done to honour those promises. The Government is, no doubt, anxious to retain some measure of respect for the promises it gave, and is now resorting to a series of shifts and devices in an effort to avoid giving effect to its promises. National insurance already has been investigated in Australia by a royal commission which furnished an invaluable report that, at the time of tabling, enabled, I should say, a reasonable picture to be visualized of the position of Australia in respect of national insurance. No action was taken by the Government at that time, but the present Government has attempted to revive its prestige with the public by making frequent allusions to what it describes as its policy in this connexion. Last year it had the benefit of the services of two highly competent actuaries who, the Treasurer (Mr. Casey) has in formed me, have supplied answers to a series of questions submitted to them. The Government of Western Australia made available to the Commonwealth an actuary of great experience, who has been engaged at Canberra with the actuary of the Australian Mutual Provident Society, who also has had long experience and is a most competent man. Those gentlemen finished their work some four months ago. Prior to the completion of their work, the Government decided that it would have a survey made of the European experience of national insurance, and informed this House that it had commissioned the honorable member for Parramatta (Sir Frederick Stewart), who was at that time Parliamentary UnderSecretary for Employment, to make this investigation. The honorable gentleman has completed his inquiries, and has furnished his report to the Government. All the data which any government anxious to do something in this matter needs is now available. A British expert can tell us nothing about the difficulties regarding national insurance in Australia, which is not discoverable in this country by examination of the very voluminous literature available in respect of the British national insurance system. I have not the least doubt that Sir Frederick Stewart's survey included data concerning the working of the British system.

speech.para: The Government now, as the result of consultation with honorable members, not in this chamber, but within the precincts of this House, and in order to allay their impatience as to the inaction of the Government, contemplates incurring additional expense. Investigations which have been made by Ministers and their staffs in regard to economic, trade and other questions outside Australia, during the last five years, have already cost this country about £50,000. and in addition, royal commissions set up in Australia have cost thousands more. To me it appears extraordinary that no sooner has one report been tabled than the Government calmly proceeds to have a further investigation made by some other person regarding the report already before it. I object to this procedure as being unnecessary, costly, and extravagant. It cannot have any other motive than to stalemate action on matters on which the Government has pledged itself to act. I hope that wiser counsels will prevail, and that this matter will not be held up until' we get the benefit of any expert Great Britain is in a position to make available, lt will be three months before the British expert can visit Australia. He will have to survey all the findings and data collected by the Commonwealth Government, and that will take some time.

talk.start.para: - About an hour and a quarter.
- An hour and a quarter ! If all that is involved is that a British expert should visit Australia and make up his mind in an hour and a quarter-
- That is the time that it will take him to read the available data.

speech.para: Mi-. CURTIN.- Well then, post it to him and tell him to read it in Great Britain and to send a letter ! That would be just effective as a survey here taking an hour and a quarter. One of the features of the conduct of Australian affairs by this Government and a similar government which preceded it some years ago, has been a desire to bring out to Australia advisers from overseas. The inability of the Treasurer to give me an effective answer as to. what action the Government proposes to take in regard to interest rates probably explains why Sir Ernest Harvey was brought from Great Britain to this country some years ago I see no occasion for bringing another British expert to Australia to deal with our problem of national insurance. Statesmanship is not so bankrupt in this country, however deficient it may be on the treasury benches, as to be unable to formulate a system of national insurance if we are determined to formulate it. I object to the futile, vexatious, and delaying intentions of the Government, and also to its efforts to evade giving effect to the definite and decisive promises given at the election in 1934 that it would take steps to bring down a system of national insurance. Half of the life of this Parliament has gone, and we are no nearer having an outline of the Government's policy than we were when we first assembled. I object to the conduct which has marked the Government's handling of this matter.

talk.start.para: .- I cannot let pass this opportunity to refer to a subject of great importance and urgency. Two days ago I asked the Prime Minister what attitude was being taken by the Government regarding the sentence of death recently passed by ths Supreme Court of the Mandated Territory of New Guinea on a white man, one Ludwig Schmidt. I received the following reply from the right honorable gentleman this morning: -

quote.para: On 18th March, the honorable member for Griffith asked me whether a sentence of death recently passed by a court in the Mandated Territory upon a white man named Ludwig Schmidt would be carried out. I then informed the honorable member that when a decision was arrived at it would be made known.

I am now in a position to state that the Administrator of New Guinea has reported that the sentence of death imposed on Ludwig Schmidt upon three separate counts of wilful murder was confirmed on 19th March, and that the execution of the prisoner has been fixed for 25th March, 1930.

The crime for which Schmidt has been convicted was committed on the mainland of New Guinea in August, 1934, and at the time of the crime the accused wa3 one of a party consisting of himself and three other Europeans.
Two of the other Europeans were sentenced to terms of imprisonment, one to a term of ten years on the charge of grievous assault, and the other to seven years on the charge of abduction with intent.

The law of the Territory of New Guinea vests in the Supreme Court of the territory jurisdiction over all crimes and offences against the law. The High Court may grant leave to appeal to the High Court from any conviction or sentence of the Supreme Court of the territory.

In cases punishable with death, the carrying out of any capital sentence shall not take place without the sanction obtained under the hand and the seal of the Administrator. The law also empowers the Administrator to remit any sentence imposed by a court exercising criminal jurisdiction in the territory and to commute any sentence of death and substitute therefor a term of imprisonment.

speech.para: My object in bringing this matter forward is not with the intention of debating the justice or otherwise of the punishment inflicted, because the case has already been dealt with by a properly constituted judicial authority, and I trust that if any reference is made to it by honorable members that fact will be borne in mind. As Parliament is not' a judicial assembly matters of this nature cannot be considered as dispassionately as they would be in a court of law. I bring the matter forward because, since the inception of federation, no white man has ever suffered the death penalty under a federal law, whether a statute of the Commonwealth or an ordinance promulgated in the Territory of New Guinea or any other territory under the control of the Commonwealth. When the right honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Scullin) was Prime Minister, two residents of New Guinea were sentenced to death. In each instance the Administrator was instructed by the Government not to give effect to the sentence ; and in neither case was the death sentence carried out. I am not one of those who believe that punishment by death is a preventive, because it has been found that capital punishment is valueless when studied from that viewpoint.

talk.start.para: - It would prevent this man from committing any more crimes.

- That is a particularly callous remark. It has been found that capital punishment is not a deterrent. If the only desire is to prevent a repetition of such crimes, imprisonment for life should be quite sufficient. The old argument of those who support capital punishment is that it is the only way to prevent the repetition of certain crimes. In Great Britain, many years ago, over 100 felonies were punishable by death, and there are instances on record in which children between the ages of seven and nine years were executed. In such cases capital punishment was valueless. The Queensland government, in accordance with its policy, has abolished capital punishment, and in so doing has proved the inaccuracy of the contention that, if abolished, crimes for which death is the penalty would increase. Although capital punishment has been abolished in Queensland, there has not been an increase of the number of crimes committed.

speech.para: Another important phase of this subject is that, apparently by an oversight of this Parliament, full power is given to the administrators of these territories to deal with such matters. They possess powers which this Parliament, under the Constitution, cannot give to itself. In the instructions given to the Governor-
General under Letters Patent of the Commonwealth, we find the following -

quote.para: And we do hereby direct and enjoin that our said Governor-General shall not pardon or reprieve any such offender- without first receiving in capital cases the advice of the Executive Council for our said Commonwealth, and in other cases the advice of one, at least, of his Ministers;

speech.para: The Governor-General's power to reprieve is thus limited, yet in the case of crimes committed in New Guinea or any other territory under the control of the Commonwealth, this Parliament has by legislation deprived the Commonwealth Government of the power to reprieve. Under ordinances made in New Guinea and approved by this Parliament, the Administrator has full power. It was decided in the case Bex v. Bernasconi in 1915 that the laws of the Commonwealth did not include the laws of the territories. Evidently owing to an oversight of this Parliament the Administrator has full power in these matters, and therefore is able and has to decide whether this man shall suffer the full penalty of his offence. I am suggesting that the Government, if willing, should approach the Administrator who would certainly give very careful consideration to whatever advice it tendered. It is the duty of the Government to inquire fully into the matter. Even if it has not the power to reprieve it could give directions to the present Administrator, who, incidentally is an ex-member of this Parliament, and it is practically certain that its wishes would be respected. The sentence of death will be carried out on Wednesday next unless the Government inquires into the matter as it would have to do had the person concerned been a citizen of the Commonwealth. The Government should at least decide whether the sentence should or should not be carried out, and in doing so should give careful consideration to the fact that since the inception of Federation not one white man has ever suffered capital punishment for an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth or any ordinance of the Territory of New Guinea. If the sentence is carried out, it will be an unfortunate blot upon the fair name of the Commonwealth and its good record will be spoiled.

talk.start.para: .- I desire to bring under the notice of the

speech.para: Minister in charge of War Service Homes (Mr. Thorby) a case of hardship which merits more considerate action on the part of the Government than is indicated in the communications I have received from the Minister. I consider it undesirable to mention the name of the person concerned, but I am willing to hand it to the Minister. I shall state the facts briefly and leave honorable members to determine whether they consider that the woman concerned does not deserve more sympathetic consideration. The case relates to the ownership and occupancy of a war service home in South Australia. The woman with her husband, who later deserted from her, was a joint owner of the home, and she has since secured a divorce. She is responsible for the maintenance of herself and the circumstances compel her to support the children. Up to last De'cember when this matter was administered by the State Bank of South Australia, which was acting as agents for the War Service Home Commission, she made an acceptable arrangement to pay 7s. 6d. a week, plus an amount of 10s. a month for rates while she occupied the home, but when the War Service Homes Department assumed control of war service homes in South Australia the weekly payment was increased from 7s. 6d. to 15s. She made endeavours to maintain the payments, but' as the total income into the home is only £1 18s. a week, she is unable to continue to do so, and at the same time, provide even the meanest comforts for the members of her family. The commission has adopted a very hard, and I feel, unwarranted, attitude in determining her occupancy of the home, because of her inability to maintain these heavy commitments. This week I received from the Minister in charge of War Service Homes, the following communication : -
. . I desire to inform you that that lady ia not eligible for assistance under the War Service Homes Act.

I take it that the Minister means the leniency provisions .of the act in respect of widows, but I maintain that this woman has a disability in actual fact equal to that of a woman whose husband has died. The letter continues -

quote.para: I understand that Mrs.- has divorced her husband who previously had deserted her. The commission lias extended full assistance, but I regret (that the arrears cannot be permitted to accumulate further. Continued occupation cannot be given to Mrs.- unless she pays the full rental value. In the circumstances, therefore, she 1ms .been called upon to vacate the home, and I suggest that this action should bo taken.

speech.para: As there has been nothing in her behaviour to which exception could possibly be taken, and because she has made every attempt to meet her obligations, I consider that the commission has dealt very harshly with her case. She had the misfortune to make a bad choice in her selection of a life partner from whom she had to secure release, and now, because of her inability to discharge fully the added liability imposed upon her, she is called upon to vacate her home. The Minister might very well give consideration to the application of the leniency provisions of the War Service Homes Act in this case. If that is not possible, surely arrangements could be made to revert to the original agreement entered into with the State Bank as agent for the War Service Homes Commission. I commend the case of this woman to the sympathetic consideration of the Minister in charge of War Service Homes.

talk.start.para: . - I support the protest made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin). Among the people generally there is growing disappointment and disgust at the failure of the Government to honour its election promise to provide a scheme of national insurance. A very costly royal commission was set up by the Bruce-Page Government some years ago to inquire into this matter. A great deal of evidence taken by that commission must be still available in the Prime Minister's Department. Every year since then the Government has sent a tripartite delegation to the International Labour Conference and for the last ten years the question of national insurance has been discussed in some form or other; sometimes only in passing, but at others as one of the leading items on the agenda paper. Surely it is not suggested that the expert from England will be able to supply the Treasurer, or the Government, with more information than has been compiled by the International Labour Office. The Australian delegate to the International Labour Conference,' who has recently returned to Australia made special inquiries into this subject. During the last ten years every volume issued by the International Labour Office has contained detailed information in respect of national schemes of social insurance. The English scheme has been fully dealt with in those publications. Only last week I received a voluminous report from the Intel-national Labour Office, containing in detail particulars of every scheme of national insurance adopted by the countries of the world. I am certain that the technical expert to be brought from England cannot simply more information than may be gleaned from that report. In all probability, that gentleman would, himself, have given evidence which appears in that report. The fear that the Government merely intends to postpone this question until the eve of an election is causing the growing discontent among the people of Australia.

speech.para: I was asked recently by a large deputation to urge the Government to consider the restoration of the 2s. cut still being made in invalid and old-age pensions. Commonwealth Public Service asociations have made representations that the cuts in their salaries should be restored. On every hand there is growing impatience at the failure of the Government to honour its promises. Certainly the pensions of soldiers' dependants are now paid in full, but the restoration involved only a small amount. The Government may deem it wise to make restorations involving only a small sum first ; but Commonwealth Public Servants in receipt of low salaries were definitely promised that whenever the finances of the country would permit, they would be the first to have their cuts restored. The honoring of this promise would not involve a large sum. Yet nothing has been done. It is now felt that the finances of the country have improved sufficiently during the last three years to warrant the full restoration of the cuts applied to salaries and social services during the period of financial emergency. During the last three or four years an average of £3,000,000 a year has been provided for the relief of primary .producers. No honorable member on this side of the House complains about that. I have not had an opportunity to examine the figures, but I think it can be safely said that during the last three or four years, remissions of taxation amounting to over £1,000,000 annually have been made to people who were not affected by the financial emergency legislation. But if during that same period the Government has remitted two or three millions of pounds more than would be required to make good its promises, the impatience of the pensioners and public servants is justified. It has been pointed out that all parties in this Parliament were unanimous that, at the first opportunity, the invalid and old-age pensions, and the salaries of public servants, would be restored to their former level. Remissions have been made of land., sales and income taxes, but these have benefited mostly the wealthy sections of the community. In addition, £4,000,000 or £5,000,000 has been given to the struggling primary producers in the form of subsidies and bounties, yet the only restoration of salaries and pensions has been a slight repayment to ex-soldiers' dependants, and a small increase of the salaries of public servants. No restoration, except the 6d. which automatically became due by reason of the increase of the cost of living, has been made to the invalid and old-age pensioners.

Investigation into the subject of national insurance by a visitor from overseas, no matter how eminent an authority he may be, would be a sheer waste of time from the point of view of the public, though useful politically to the Government. The latest proposal of the Ministry is an insult to the intelligence of the experts whom we have in Australia.,, and who could well supply all the information required.

talk.start.para: .- Speaking in this chamber recently, the honorable member for "Watson (Mr. Jennings) remarked that he had visited Hobart, and had found that apples of good quality were not obtainable there. He said he regretted that the people of Sydney could not secure good fruit from Tasmania. I do not believe that the honorable member intended to do an injury to my State. In the interests of the apple and pear industry in my State I point out that the best varieties are not available until after Easter. The

speech.para: State Government has appointed an officer to supervise the distribution of the best fruit, and I believe that about 30,000 eases of Tasmanian apples are supplied to the Sydney market weekly when the season is in full operation. Tasmania can produce apples and pears at least equal in quality to those grown in New South Wales or any other State.

talk.start.para: . - I did not have the privilege of hearing all the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin), but I caught the general drift of them. The Government has not made any statement in public with regard to national insurance, although a report appeared in the press this morning purporting to give the result of a party meeting held yesterday. This was a very brief account of what transpired. The Leader of the Opposition himself asked me a question this morning, and I replied that the Government would take into consideration a proposal that a leading British expert on the subject of national insurance should be invited to visit Australia. The Government has not yet considered the matter, but it will do so in the near future. The honorable gentleman treated the subject lightly, as though anybody with a reasonable amount of intelligence could prepare a national insurance scheme for Australia, and contended that, as we had already made careful investigation into the subject, further inquiries were unnecessary. I have the highest opinion of the ability of the Leader of the Opposition, and of some, at least, of the gentlemen whom he has the honour to lead, but the introduction of a complete scheme is a matter the magnitude, importance and complexity of which I am afraid he does not quite appreciate. If such a proposal were put into operation, it would affect the social conditions of the 6,500,000 people in Australia. It would involve an attempt to give the average person security against all the ills against which he is not now able to insure himself.
- Are there not men in Australia with sufficient brains for this task?

- I have no doubt that the honorable member considers that there are, but the problem of evolving a complete scheme means more than getting two actuaries, no matter, how clever they may be, to work on the subject for a few months. If I have any voice in the matter, I shall try to ensure that we get all the expert opinion that we possibly can, before Australia is committed to a scheme of this magnitude, and before a burden of many millions of pounds is placed on industry.
- The burden is already carried by industry.

- A complete scheme would involve a burden far heavier than that already borne. The Leader of the Opposition ignored the fact that, in the inauguration of the sales tax - a comparatively minor matter - the greatest expert that Canada could produce was invited to Australia, and rightly so, so that his advice might be obtained.
- But no investigation had previously been made in this country on that subject.

- The royal commission made an investigation into certain phases of national insurance. Its inquiries were conducted ten years ago, and all the figures were entirely different then from those to-day. The Government would be justified in inviting any number of experts to come here, before it committed the country to such a scheme. We have reports on paper of what has been done in this direction in other countries, but we have not yet the information required on which a definite plan for Australia could be based. I am sure that, on reflection, the Leader of the Opposition will realize that he has made an error in raising this subject.

speech.para: I desire to inform honorable members that yesterday afternoon, the 19th March, after the representative of the German Government had submitted to the Council of the League of Nations the reasons for its action, the Council decided unanimously, the votes of the guaranteed powers not being counted, that there had been a breach of articles 42 and 43 of the Treaty of Peace, which refer to the demilitarized zone of the Rhineland. The Council has adjourned until to-day, when it will discuss future procedure. In the meantime the Locarno powers, other than Germany, are continuing their consultation with a view to arriving at an agreement which will be acceptable to all parties. Prior to the vote of the Council, all State members submitted their views, and I give for the information of honorable members the view expressed by the Commonwealth Government representative, Mr. Bruce -

quote.para: I listened this morning with groat attention to the very full statement which was made by. the German (representative. It has however, not altered my views as to the proper course which it is my duty to pursue in regard to the immediate issue that is before the Council. That issue arises out of the Locarno agreements, to which some of us at this Council table were not parties. That fact, however, does not mean that we have not a very great interest and a great responsibility in regard to the situation which has arisen. We have one immediate duty. That duty arises under article 4 of the Treaty of Locarno, which reads - " If one of the High Contracting Parties alleges that a violation of article 2 of the present treaty or a breach of articles 42 or 4.'! of the Treaty of Versailles has been, or is being, committed, it shall bring the question at once before the Council of the League of Nations. As soon as the Council of the League of Nations is satisfied that such violation or breach has been committed it will notify its finding without delay to the powers signatory of the present treaty".

The governments of France and Belgium have brought to the notice of the Council of the League circumstances such as are contemplated in article 4, and the representative of France, on behalf of France and Belgium has submitted a resolution, inviting the Council to declare that the German Government has committed a breach of article 43 of the Treaty of Versailles and of the Locarno Treaty. Upon that resolution it is now the duty of the Council to pronounce. On behalf of the Government of Australia, I declare that I propose to vote in favour of the resolution. The duties of the Council, however, are not concluded by such a pronouncement, and the notification of the decision of the Council to the signatories of the Treaty of Locarno. A further duty is imposed on the Council, because the Treaty of Locarno was made part of the general system for the maintenance of security and world peace, which is the basis of the Covenant of the League. Article 7 of the Treaty of Locarno stipulates - "The present treaty which is designed to ensure the maintenance of peace and is in conformity with the Covenant of the League of Nations, shall not be interpreted as restricting the duty of the League to take whatever action may be deemed wise and effectual to safeguard the peace of the world ".

The issue which confronts us to-day is fundamental to the whole system that it has been the endeavour of the nations to create since the termination of the world war. That system is based on the scrupulous observance of treaties, and upon the fact that no power can free itself from the obligations it has undertaken by unilateral action. It is now for the powers primarily concerned to take counsel with a view to resolving the situation which now confronts us. During the period that must elapse while these important negotiations are proceeding it is essential that all the powers concerned should individually be prepared to make some contribution towards the maintenance of the situation until a satisfactory solution can be found. I am not without hope that such a measure of cooperation will be forthcoming. The statements made by the representatives of France and Belgium showed, under the most trying conditions,a restraint and moderation that has impressed the world. In many speeches the German Chancellor has expressed his willingness and his desire to live in peace and friendship, and to co-operate in creating a true European solidarity. That sentiment was again reiterated on behalf of the German people by their representative this morning. Surely in this atmosphere it will be possible for a solution to be found. But behind the immediate issue which confronts us is the wide question of the whole system for the maintenance of security and peace in the world. To the solution of that problem must bo addressed the minds not only of the Locarno powers of the State members of the League, but of all nations. In the light of the experience of the years since the war, it is necessary that we should review the whole system of co-operation and common action for the maintenance of these great ideals. In this task it is the duty of the Council of the League to give a lead. Fundamental to such a system is the sanctity of treaties. Unless, as a result of that review, we can so strengthen the system as to ensure the fulfilment of its obligations by every nation, it is idle to persist in an ideal which engenders a sense of false security, and which creates incalculable dangers.

talk.start.para: . - The honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Makin) has brought to my notice the complaint of a woman who had been occupying a war service home in South Australia. The facts associated with that, case indicate that it is not within my power to do as the honorable member has suggested. Under the bill passed last year to amend the "War Service Homes Act, the Minister is authorized to make certain concessions to widows or widowed mothers of war service homes purchasers and also to wives of returned soldier purchasers of war service homes who are permanently or temporarily insane. There is no provision enabling the Minister to give relief to a woman who has been deserted by her husband or has been divorced. Some line of demarcation must be drawn. This woman was deserted by her husband and then, I understand, she applied for a divorce which has been granted. Prior to the action for divorce she had been receiving certain concessions from the State Bank which had control of the home occupied by her. "When the War Service Homes Commission took over her home, it made no alteration, until recently, in the conditions under which she was occupying it.
- The conditions were altered in December last.

- I understand that is so. She was notified that she would be required to vacate the house or pay the ordinary rental value of the property. But no adverse action has been taken against her; that is to say, no eviction order has been issued.
- Alias not the Minister discretionary power to permit the arrangement made by the State Bank to continue.
- No ; but in many cases I have been using my influence with the commission to restrain that body from taking drastic action.
- This House would not object to the Minister's giving consideration to such cases.

- I have been conferring with the Commissioner, urging that leniency be shown in all deserving cases, and I give the honorable member my assurance that what can be done in this case will be done. I am at a disadvantage in that I have no knowledge of the extent of the woman's family responsibilities, but I shall see if further assistance can be granted to her. Perhaps she will be willing to move into a cheaper house or to sub-let portion of the home which she 13 occupying, and thus obtain sufficient revenue to meet the demands made upon her. I give the honorable member my personal assurance that I shall give careful consideration to his representations.

. - The honorable member for Griffith (Mr. Baker-) has referred to the sentence of death passed on a man named Ludwig Schmidt in the Mandated Territory of New Guinea. The circumstances are much as he has described them. Pull power is given to the Administrator to deal with a matter of this kind, under an ordinance passed in 1921, of which there has been no alteration by successive governments. This power was referred to in the New Guinea Act, passed in 1932, but no alteration of the procedure was then made. It is true that, according to the records, no white man has been executed in New Guinea during the period mentioned by the honorable member ; but sentence of death was carried out in the case of two natives in December, 1932.
- No white man has previously been sentenced to death in the mandated territory.
Possibly that is the case. So far as the papers disclose, three charges of wilful murder were laid against this man, and he was found guilty on the evidence of ten witnesses.
- Three separate charges ?
- Yes, three charges of wilful murder.
- Is it the practice in the mandated territory to have a jury of four?
- There is no jury system.

- His Honor the Judge of the Supreme Court brought in the verdict of guilty against Schmidt. He stated that, on the evidence of ten native witnesses, he had no hesitation in finding the prisoner guilty.
- It is a terrific penalty to have imposed on the judicial decision of one man, and is not in conformity with our practice.

- It is at variance with our practice. It appears that on different occasions discussions have taken place as to whether the practice should be varied, and no action in that direction has been taken, largely on account of the fact, of which cognizance should be taken, that Australia holds this territory under mandate and has to account for everything that it does not to its own administration hut to other administrations. It seems to me that that fact is of some importance in a matter of this kind.
- Even if the Government has not the power to interfere with the verdict, if it communicated with the Administrator I take it that he would carry out its instructions.

- I listened to what the honorable member had to say regarding the practice of a Labour administration. Without doubting his word, I should like to have further inquiries made, because' I understand that the last administration merely requested the Administrator to report to the Government, and took no steps to alter his power or to interfere with his prerogatives in. this regard.
- I consulted the previous Prime Minister, the right honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Scullin) and he stated that his Government had communicated with the Administrator on two occasions.
- Those communications related to Papua, not to the mandated territory of New Guinea.

- My mind is exercised by some slight doubt, because I have consulted one whom I regard as an almost equally good authority in the late Government, and the view expressed to me is that which I have stated. However, this is a matter which I think can easily be cleared up by a further examination of the papers.
- Meanwhile, will the Government defer the execution pending further inquiries?

- The protection of the community has to be considered. The conditions in New Guinea are not the same as those that exist in Australia. I put it to the House, not cold-bloodedly, but as a simple fact, that we not only have a responsibility towards a man who commits the crime of wilful murder, but also have to ensure the safety of prospectors and other citizens of the territory, and to see to the maintenance of peaceful conditions and the preservation of law and order.
- Also the protection of the natives against brutality.

Exactly. We have to answer to the Mandates Commission for the manner in which we discharge our obligations. I cannot give offhand the undertaking asked for by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin), but I can assure him and the House that a meeting of Cabinet will be held before the date fixed for the execution, and it will investigate and consider the matter fully, just as it would if. sentence of death were passed upon a person in Australia, with whom the Executive Council would have the power to deal.

talk.start.para: s. - On the 18th March, the honorable member for Griffith (Mr. Baker) asked me whether a sentence of death recently passed by a court in the Mandated Territory upon a white man named Ludwig Schmidt would be carried out. I then informed the honorable member that when a decision was arrived at it would be made known. I am now in a position to state that the Administrator of New Guinea has reported that the sentence of death imposed on Ludwig Schmidt upon three separate counts of wilful murder was confirmed on the 19 th March, and that the execution of the prisoner has been fixed for the 25th March, 1936. The crime for which Schmidt has been convicted was committed on the mainland of New Guinea in August, 1934, and at the time of the crime the accused was one of a party consisting of himself and three other Europeans. Two of the other Europeans were sentenced to terms of imprisonment, one to a term of ten years on the charge of grievous assault, and the other to seven years on the charge of abduction with intent. The law of the Territory of New Guinea vests in the Supreme Court of the territory jurisdiction over all crimes and offences against the law. The High Court may grant leave to appeal to the High Court from any conviction or sentence of the Supreme Court of the territory. In cases punishable with death, the carrying out of any capital sentence shall not take place without the sanction obtained, under the hand and the seal of the Administrator. The law also empowers' the Administrator to remit any sentence imposed by a court exercising criminal jurisdiction in the territory and to commute any sentence of death and* substitute therefor a term of imprisonment.
